question: Psychiatrists and psychologists label behavior as disordered when it is
choice3: biologically influenced, unconsciously motivated, and difficult to change.

question: Ongoing patterns of behavior that are different from those of most other people in your culture are best characterized as
Ongoing patterns of behavior that interfere with normal day-to-day life are best characterized as
Mira claims that alcohol dependence is a disease that, like pneumonia or meningitis, can be cured or prevented with proper treatment. Her belief is most clearly consistent with

Dr. McIntosh emphasizes that depression often involves the interactive influences of negative self-focused reflection, rejection from others, and low serotonin levels. Dr. McIntosh's emphasis best illustrates
A psychotherapist is most likely to use the DSM-IV-TR in order to _____ various psychological disorders.
choice2: test patients' in order to confirm the presence of
choice3: evaluate the effectiveness of prescribed medication for

question: In a study by David Rosenhan (1973), researchers were admitted as patients into various mental hospitals after they falsely claimed to be “hearing voices.” This study best illustrated the negative effects of

After Anika learned that her history teacher had suffered an anxiety disorder, she began to take notice of the teacher's tendency to talk loudly and assumed it was simply a way of disguising feelings of personal insecurity. This best illustrates the
choice2: impact of students' observations on the teacher's behavior.

question: Although labelling someone as having a psychological disorder may have unintended negative consequences, it is necessary because
choice1: names of patients with disorders must be entered into a database shared with law enforcement.
choice2: it ensures patients will not receive a conflicting diagnosis from another doctor.
choice4: employers must be notified of employee's diagnosis.
choice3: mental health professionals can quickly communicate the characteristics of their patients' complex symptoms.

question: Anxiety is considered a disorder if it is
choice1: causes the onset of memory loss.

question: Rishi, a college student, complains that about a year ago he began feeling apprehensive and tense but doesn't know why. Without apparent reason, he worries and now suffers from high blood pressure. Additionally, he sometimes has heart palpatations and feels shakey. From which of the following disorders is Rishi most likely to suffer?
Kaylee is so afraid of spiders and insects that she avoids most outdoor activities and even refuses to go to the basement of her own house alone. Kaylee appears to suffer from a(n)

While he was studying, Matthew was suddenly overwhelmed by feelings of intense apprehension. For several minutes he felt so agitated that he could not catch his breath. Matthew was most likely suffering from a(n)

Ravi brushes his teeth 18 times a day. Each time, he uses exactly 83 strokes up and 83 strokes down. After he eats, he must brush twice with two different brands of toothpaste. Ravi most likely suffers from a(n)
Two years after being brutally beaten and raped, Brenda still experiences jumpy anxiety, has trouble sleeping, and has vivid flashbacks of her assault. Brenda is most clearly showing signs of
Cancer survivors who develop a fresh delight in their children and savor the joy of each new day best illustrate

Melissa is fearful of men and refuses to go out on dates. Her therapist suggests that she is fearful because she was sexually abused by her father when she was young. The therapist's suggestion most clearly reflects a ________ perspective.

Julius is obsessed with avoiding germs and feels compelled to bathe at least 10 times every day. His therapist suggests that Julius continues his maladaptive bathing because this behavior temporarily reduced his anxiety on many past occasions, so he has conditioned himself to use bathing to reduce his feelings of stress. The therapist's suggestion most directly reflects a ________ perspective because he has conditioned himself to bathe to reduce anxiety.

A traumatic experience may trigger a lasting phobia in a child with a sensitive, high-strung temperament. The same experience, however, may have no long-term impact on a child with a more relaxed temperament. This best illustrates the role of ________ in the development of phobias.

Saul frequently feels like he has a lump in his throat that makes it difficult for him to speak or swallow. Medical examinations, however, indicate that there is no apparent physical cause for these symptoms. Saul appears to be suffering from a

Rachel is convinced that her occasional headaches are caused by a malignant brain tumor. Although several physicians have assured her that she has no serious physical problem, Rachel continues to seek medical attention for a brain tumor. Her behavior provides an example of

Several weeks after being fired from a job he had held for more than 20 years, Landon awoke one morning in a state of bewildered confusion. He had little sense of who he was and even failed to recognize his wife. Landon's experience is most indicative of
The major characteristic of dissociative disorders is a disturbance of

Niesha's seven different personalities appear to take turns controlling her behavior. None of her alternate personalities are aware of each other or of each other's experiences or memories. It is likely that Niesha may be diagnosed with ________ disorder.

Midori's therapist suggests that she developed a dissociative identity disorder as a way of protecting herself from a unconscious hatred for her abusive mother. The therapist's suggestion most directly reflects a ________ perspective.
Major depressive disorder is said to occur when signs of depression last at least

Following the death of her husband a couple months ago, Gabrielle has felt lethargic and often is unable to get out of bed in the morning. She has withdrawn from friends and family because she feels worthless and hopeless. Gabrielle is most likely suffering from

After several weeks of feeling apathetic and dissatisfied with his life, Mark has become wildly excited for no apparent reason, is extremely talkative and suddenly has an exceptionally positive but unrealistic outlook on life. He seems to need less sleep and becomes irritated when his friends tell him to slow down. Mark's behavior is indicative of
Research regarding depression indicates that
choice1: with each new generation, depression is increasing in its prevalence.
choice2: depression is unlikely to be overcome without professional help.
choice3: men are two times more likely than women to be diagnosed with depression.
choice4: having an episode of depression does not increase the likelihood of experiencing depression in the future.

question: While attending orientation for her new job at a mental hospital, Mary visits a ward where schizophrenic patients live. Which of the following patients would she most likely NOT see there?
choice1: Mitchell who has 7 personalities, each of whom speak in a different voice.
choice2: Wilma who reports hearing voices telling her that she is worthless and should jump from the window.
choice3: Marly who believes the nurses are poisoning the patients.
choice4: Mr. Hunt who believes he is Abraham Lincoln's grandfather.

question: Research on the causes of schizophrenia strongly suggests that
choice1: almost anybody will develop schizophrenia if exposed to extensive environmental stress.
choice2: a detached or permissive parenting style may increase chances of schizophrenia in children.
choice3: there is a correlation between schizophrenia and prenatal exposure to viral infection in the womb.
choice4: if adopted children's adoptive parents have schizophrenia, they will, too.

question: Those with a narcissistic personality disorder are likely to be preoccupied with

Anthony created a series of lies to swindle his elderly aunt out of her life's savings. Although he left her with no money to purchase her medications or pay her heating bill, he felt no remorse. His behavior is likely to be evidence of
Researchers recently estimated that approximately ________ percent of adult Americans had suffered a clinically significant psychological disorder during the prior year.
Which of the following is a risk factor correlated to diagnosis of psychological disorders?

Dr. Byrne is a clinical psychologist who often uses operant conditioning techniques to treat her clients. She also encourages them to modify their thought patterns, and on occasion she interprets their transference behaviors. Dr. Byrne's therapeutic approach would best be described as
Mr. Choi's therapist wants to help him become aware of his conflicting childhood feelings of love and hate for his parents. The therapist's goal best reflects a primary aim of
Psychological therapy known as psychoanalysis was introduced by
Sheena's therapist tells her to relax, close her eyes, and state aloud whatever comes to mind no matter how trivial or absurd. The therapist is using a free association technique that is central to
Psychoanalytic techniques are designed primarily to help patients
choice2: gain insight concerning their repressed conflicts and impulses.

question: Which of the following is NOT commonly associated with psychoanalysis?
Instead of focusing on the cure of psychological disorders, ________ therapies seek to promote personal growth and self-fulfillment.
Lynn has begun to buy small gifts for her therapist, and she feels extremely jealous of the time he spends with his other patients. To a psychoanalyst, this is most indicative of

Nate's past relationships with his mother, his former wife, and his previous employer have been characterized by common patterns of resentment and emotional detachment. Helping Nate gain insight into these recurring relationship patterns would be of greatest concern to a
In the humanistic approach, which technique emphasizes the importance of therapists providing patients with unconditional positive regard so that the patients are open to self-reflection?

During a marriage counseling session, the therapist suggests to Mr. and Mrs. Gallo that they each restate their spouse's comments before making their own. The therapist was asking the couple to use a technique known as

Cindy's previous therapist suggested that her nail biting might be a symptom of unconscious resentment toward her parents. However, her new therapist said, “No, Cindy, your problem isn't unconscious hostility; your problem is nail biting, and you can learn not to do it.” Cindy's new therapist sounds most like a ________ therapist.

In one treatment for bed-wetting, the child sleeps on a liquid-sensitive pad that when wet, triggers an alarm and awakens the child. This treatment that uses stimulus and response modification is a form of

In an effort to reduce his daughter's fear of the dark, Mr. Chew would hug and gently rock her immediately after turning off the lights at bedtime. Mr. Chew's strategy best illustrates the technique of

Jonathan is afraid to ask a girl for a date, so his therapist uses an exposure therapy technique in which Jonathan first relaxes and simply imagines he is reaching for a telephone and then calling a potential date. After he becomes comfortable with doing that, the therapist has him rehearse conversations with a female on the phone, with the hope of eventually working up to asking for a date. The therapist's technique best illustrates the process of

Sylvia has a fear of spiders. One of the techniques used by her behavioral therapists is to have Sylvia view pictures of spiders on the computer. Which of the following methods is being employed by her therapist?

Melanie is seeking treatment to treat nail biting. Her behavioral therapist suggests that she paint her fingernails with a bitter-tasting nail polish to provide a negative response when she bites her nails. This procedure best illustrates
Praising socially withdrawn children when they have eye contact with others and ignoring them after a temper tantrum best illustrates an application of

To encourage Mrs. Coleman, a withdrawn schizophrenia patient, to be more socially active, institutional staff members give her small plastic cards whenever she talks to someone. She is allowed to exchange these cards for candy and cigarettes. Staff members are making use of which behavioral therapy technique?

Bob is very bothered by his teacher's suggestions for improving his study habits. He feels defeated because he has interpreted her comments to mean that he is going to fail the course. Bob would most likely benefit from ___ therapy to help him learn to overcome negative self-talk after an unpleasant experience.

Nadia believed that her failure to get A's in all her courses meant she was incompetent and would be a failure in college. Her therapist calmly challenged her negative assertion, commenting, “By your strange calculations, well over 90 percent of all students are incompetent!” The therapist's response was most typical of a(n) ________ therapist.
Which of the following describes Aaron Beck's cognitive therapy technique for helping depressed clients?
choice2: utilizing operant conditioning to change undesirable behaviors.
choice1: using gentle questioning to help patients recognize their own irrational thinking

question: Although Ethan is actually doing very well in college, he feels depressed and academically incompetent. To cause him to focus on his positive attributes, his therapist has instructed him to explain in writing how his own hard work and personal abilities contributed to each of the good grades he received during the previous semester. This therapeutic procedure is most characteristic of ________ therapy.

In Melanie's therapy group for compulsive gamblers, the therapist has convinced the participants to attribute their compulsive urges to abnormal brain functioning rather than blaming themselves for their "addiction." The therapist now has the group learning to not give in to an urge by engaging themselves in an alternative activity like a video game. This strategy for dealing with their difficulty best illustrates
Group therapy is typically more effective than individual therapy for
choice1: encouraging severely disturbed individuals to quickly regain normal social functioning.
choice2: enabling people to discover that others have problems similar to their own.
choice3: implementing active listening in client-centered therapy.

question: Bill's enraged tantrums escalated, and he hurt his younger sister. When Bill's parents took him to counseling, the therapist told them that no person is an island. The therapist seemed to be implying that __ therapy would be to helpful for Bill.
Research on the effectiveness of psychotherapy indicates that clients are generally satisfied with therapy. All of the following are possible reasons for the positive results EXCEPT:
choice1: therapy provides a safe, non-judgemental environment for clients.
choice2: people most often enter psychotherapy during a period of crisis and any improvement would seem positive.
choice3: insurance only pays for therapy if it is effective.
choice4: most clients feel that their therapists cared about helping them.

question: Although Shawn felt terribly depressed when he began psychotherapy, he reported feeling much happier by the time he had completed therapy and attributed his new-found happiness to successful therapy. His friends and family just seemed to think he'd returned to his normal self. It would be reasonable to attribute some of his perceived improvement to
Cognitive therapies have achieved especially favorable results in the treatment of
Which of the following scientifically unsupported treatment should be avoided?
Kammy vividly imagines being abused by her own mother while her therapist triggers eye movements by waving a finger in front of Kammy's eyes. The therapist is apparently using a technique known as
Sue believes she is suffering from seasonal affective disorder. According to the results of controlled studies, which alternative therapy might be most helpful for her?
Three benefits attributed to all psychotherapies are
choice2: hope, a new perspective, and a caring relationship.
choice3: an eclectic approach, nondirective treatment, and psychotherapy integration.

question: At his first therapy session, Mr. Gotanda described the numerous symptoms he had been experiencing to his therapist. Afterwards, he told his wife that he felt immediate relief from many of his symptoms and was filled with hope. His reaction following just one session most likely is the result of
Which of the following would likely have the LEAST effect on the formation of the therapeutic alliance between a therapist and a client?
choice1: a therapist's unconditional positive regard for their patient
choice3: hourly fee charged by the therapist

question: Dr. Miller prescribes drugs for the treatment of chronic depression, and she encourages rest and relaxation training for clients suffering from excessive anxiety. It is most likely that Dr. Miller is a
Dr. Genscher believes that most psychological disorders result from chemical abnormalities. In her work as a therapist, Dr. Genscher is most likely to make use of
Which form of therapy has most directly contributed to the sharp reduction in the number of psychological distburbed people being confined to mental hospitals?

Dr. Volz is a researcher who wants to distinguish between the direct effects of a new antianxiety medication and effects arising from expectations of the drug's effectiveness. Dr. Volz is most likely to use
Long-term use of certain antipsychotic drugs can produce involuntary movements of the facial muscles, tongue, and limbs. This menacing condition is known as

Melissa has been diagnosed with schizophrenia and suffers from auditory hallucinations and falsely believes that her teachers are trying to kill her. Melissa's has begun taking Thorazine which is a(n) ________ drugs.

To help an adult client overcome fears of venturing out of his own home, Dr. Ricci plans to use behavior therapy in combination with drug therapy. Which of the following antianxiety drug would Dr. Ricci be most likely to prescribe?
Which of the following individuals is most likely to benefit from Prozac?
choice1: Jack, who has lost his sense of identity and wandered from his home to a distant city
choice2: Andrea, who hears imaginary voices telling her that she will suffer a fatal accident
choice3: Tami, who is so addicted to cigarettes that she doesn't want to quit smoking
choice4: Shannon, who is depressed and feels helpless and apathetic

question: Mr. McCardle's excessive feelings of helplessness and despondency are periodically interrupted by episodes in which he experiences extreme feelings of personal power and a grandiose optimism about his future. Which drug would most likely be prescribed to alleviate his symptoms of bipolar disorder?

Even after taking antidepressant medication, Adelle's feelings of unhappiness, low self-esteem, and hopelessness have become so extreme that she has attempted suicide. Which of the following treatments could possibly provide her with quick relief from her misery?
Which of the following biomedical treatments for depression is used to stimulate or suppress brain activity and provides some of the benefits of ECT without triggering seizures or memory loss?
Inserting a medical instrument through each eye socket to surgically separate the frontal lobe from the emotion controlling centers of the brain was part of a treatment known as
A therapeutic life-style may help some people find relief from depression. Which of the following is NOT an important components of the therapeutic life-style approach?
All of the following are preventive mental health attempts to reduce the incidence of psychological disorders EXCEPT
choice1: establishing programs to alleviate poverty and loneliness
choice2: allowing deep brain stimulation to be conducted by certified massage therapists.
choice3: finding ways to make life meaningful and fulfilling
